data.title: Cannot read property 'folderQueries' of undefined

I just hit this in insiders selfhost. I was searching in a root folder that does not exist on disk (not sure if that has any impact):

data.title: Some abbreviations not work in scss file
data.body: 1. vscode Version: 1.15.1 2. OS: OS X El Capitan For example: When I input the emmet abbreviation 'mr' in a scss file, I expected the emmet result prompts, and after I entered TAB, the result is 'margin', not 'margin-right'.

data.title: Useless snippets in the snippets list
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: win7x64

It's great when IntelliSense gives you only necessary snippets. And after the "elem." you will (_or should_) get properties and methods, that belong to "elem".

But here is a case I've met like thousand times:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/29953988-04a0246e-8edd-11e7-96c7-568fa2540e7c.png)

Although method `"createElement"` belongs to `document` and only, once you will write that in your code - it will appear in **any** snippets list, according to matching letters.

It shows the icon of "global identifier":

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/29954152-65550eea-8ede-11e7-83dd-934ea2c29631.png)

But how is that a global identifier, just because you wrote it somewhere in the code?
I think this should be fixed.

data.title: Custom menu item
data.body:
Is possible to make extension have custom menu item in the file explorer

Here's I want to do in extension:
When user right click a folder on explorer, show an custom menu item, then user click a item "import template". pop out a dialog which shows a list of template(html, js) then user select a template to import the template code into that folder.

data.title: Not all Emmet shortcuts work
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra (12.6)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new HTML document
2. use `!` and the `TAB` key and I get the expected template
3. use the following syntax: `p[title="Hello world"]` and follow by the tab key and it does not work.

The `p[title="Hello world"]` snippet is directly from the emmet cheat sheet.

In previous versions of vscode (1.14 I believe) this `script[src="script.js"]` snippet worked fine and created `<script src="script.js"></script>`

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Git sections from other folders, in single-root mode, don't go away
data.body:
- Open one folder
- Open a single file from another folder, which has a git repo
- See that there are now two sections in the git viewlet
- Close the file
- The other section is still there

One case where this is annoying is that I have my User folder under Git, so every time I open settings, it opens the `User` git section. It's easy to collapse the extra ones though. If they don't go away automatically when the file is closed, I should be able to right-click -> hide them

data.title: Feature request: support for file path
data.body:
Right now, when doing a `new file` or `new folder` we cannot add a full path. 

I think it would be a very neat to allow a full path (probably just supporting the "/" would be enough) when creating a new file. 
For example:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/74671/29950482-f09c1c78-8e70-11e7-943d-f9668d170f50.png)
the  `src/` folder would be created if it does not exist and used as the path of the file. (This was one of my favorite Sublime plugins) 

Also, creating a folder seems to have another command to have new new file, which might not be needed. For example, the following "new item" could create a folder (as it ends with "/")
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/74671/29950637-fa1ee540-8e71-11e7-90d0-34873b46ef82.png)

Merging the "new file" and "new folder" with this feature will really make creating new file structure much more efficient. This will only save some few seconds per operation, but will bring much satisfaction. 


(This was one of my top Sublime Text plugins, and would fit perfectly in the current default VSCode new file UI)

data.title: HTML Formatter flattens YAML Front Matter
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
python|don|0.7.0
vscode-great-icons|emm|2.1.15
cpptools|ms-|0.12.3
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1
debugger-for-edge|msj|0.4.1

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create `test.html` file with yaml front matter:
    ```html
    ---
    key: value
    ---
    
    <html>
    </html>
    ```
2. Trigger format: `Alt` + `Shift` + `F`
3. Observe yaml being flattened:
    ```html
    --- key: value ---

    <html>
    </html>
    ```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Confusing highlighting of matches

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: win7x64

GIF:
![confusing highlighting of matches](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/29947756-00db0ed0-8eb4-11e7-9b86-464dd6f79705.gif)

I understand why it acts like that.
But I think it's visually confusing.
I think there is a need to remove `"this."` word where you select some letters, from matching highlighting.

data.title: Support ARM64 build for Windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: New devices are coming to market in a couple months. These are ARM64 devices running the Windows 10 OS. Can we get an officially supported build of VS Code that runs native on ARM64?

data.title: "when" clause with context keys not working anymore for custom views

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (8b942faafb2d1bee6fd6a346853548d528c7eb5a, 2017-08-31T07:27:43.804Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a custom view extension with a value of `"scmProvider == git"` for the `contributes.views.explorer.when` key in package.json.
2. Observe that the extension doesn't get activated even though the current scm provider is git.

Note that this is working in 1.15.1 and older versions.

data.title: Second Window Editor Limitations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: (All disabled)

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
python|don|0.7.0
vscode-apache|mrm|1.1.1
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1
vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.16
php-formatter|Sop|0.2.4

(1 theme extensions excluded)

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code and view a file
2. Open a new VS Code Window and open another file

Problem:

In the first instance the editor works correctly.
In the second instance the editor does not show indent guides, whitespaces (/does not load settings) and shortcuts like `ALT + Z` do not work.

I guess I'm not the only one with this problem, but I'm unsure how to name it exactly. Hence, I cannot find another issue about this.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: PHP tags inside function incorrectly scoped
data.body: - VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (8b942faafb2d1bee6fd6a346853548d528c7eb5a, 2017-08-31T07:18:42.889Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0 - Extensions: Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- ng-template|Ang|0.1.7 code-settings-sync|Sha|2.8.3 sort-lines|Tyr|1.3.0 html-snippets|abu|0.1.0 Bookmarks|ale|0.16.0 project-manager|ale|0.20.0 path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2 vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11 tslint|eg2|0.17.0 auto-rename-tag|for|0.0.14 Angular2|joh|2.4.3 ecdc|mit|0.10.3 HTMLHint|mka|0.3.3 vscode-autoprefixer|mrm|2.1.2 vscode-stylefmt|mrm|2.5.0 angular2-inline|nat|0.0.17 stylelint|shi|0.28.0 ayu|tea|0.6.0 change-case|wma|1.0.0 (4 theme extensions excluded) --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. In a php block like this: ````php date('Y')){ echo date('Y'); } ?> ```` The `?`s inside of the brackets are not colored nor scoped like the others. They are white and `text.html.php meta.embedded.line.php source.php ` while the others are orange and `punctuation.section.embedded.begin.php`.

data.title: git.enabled false doesn't disable git
data.body:
`git` integration does not respect `git.enabled = false` as it used to. I recently updated vscode insiders when this stopped working (working to disable)

- VSCode Version: 
```
Version 1.16.0-insider
Commit 8b942faafb2d1bee6fd6a346853548d528c7eb5a
Date 2017-08-31T05:16:45.400Z
Shell 1.7.3
Renderer 58.0.3029.110
Node 7.9.0
Architecture x64
```
- OS Version:
`ubuntu 16.04`

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open folder that has git with modified files
2. set `"git.enabled" = false` in both user and workspace 

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Opening WorkSpace opens wp file instead after upgrade
data.body:
Insiders 8-31 
Windows 7

After upgrading from Insiders 8-8 to 8-31 a working WorkSpace now opens the file not the workSpace.
This  occurs using open recent or Open WorkSpace from the file menu.

The workSpace layout/open files were also lost after the upgrade.

data.title: Open file with Ctrl+P seems to run the query on every keystroke without cancelation
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Open a project with ~150k files
2. Use Ctrl+P and type the name of a file

**Expected:**   
Search comes back within a second or two

**Actual:**   
Search takes about 10 seconds

However,      
2b. Paste the name of a file instead of typing it in

**Actual:**   
Search completes within a second or two.

Is VSCode performing the search on every keystroke and not canceling those that are obsolete?

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Breakpoints don't get triggered for extension integration tests
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (8b942faafb2d1bee6fd6a346853548d528c7eb5a, 2017-08-31T07:18:42.889Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Generate an extension with `yo code`
1. Add a breakpoint in extension code
1. Use `vscode.commands.executeCommand('extension.sayHello')` to trigger extension in one of the tests
1. Run integration tests

Breakpoint doesn't get triggered.

See this video https://giphy.com/gifs/3o7aDdJsTo4z8wVhnO/fullscreen
